completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE ROBERTS
completeLines.speech: We'll hear argument now in Garcetti v. Ceballos. Ms. Lee.

completeLines.speaker: LEE
completeLines.speech: Chief Justice Roberts, and may it please the Court: The issue presented is whether the first amendment requires protection for all public employee speech that touches on a matter of public concern without any consideration of whether the speech was expressed as a citizen. The Ninth Circuit's approach affords no consideration for the role of the speaker as a citizen or an employee at the time of the speech. This approach, however, plants a seed of a constitutional claim in virtually every speech that public employees express while carrying out their regular job duties.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SOUTER
completeLines.speech: Well, that's -- I mean, I can see - -

completeLines.speaker: CONNOR
completeLines.speech: Do you think that the Court tried to apply the Pickering test?

completeLines.speaker: LEE
completeLines.speech: The Ninth Circuit clearly did not apply the Pickering test when they were doing the initial analysis, a threshold analysis, of whether or not the speech at issue was constitutionally protected.

completeLines.speaker: CONNOR
completeLines.speech: Do you think that the Pickering test, properly applied, would have reached a different result in this case?

completeLines.speaker: LEE
completeLines.speech: Not necessarily, not the way the Ninth --

completeLines.speaker: CONNOR
completeLines.speech: It could have - -

completeLines.speaker: LEE
completeLines.speech: -- Circuit viewed it.

completeLines.speaker: CONNOR
completeLines.speech: -- certainly.

completeLines.speaker: LEE
completeLines.speech: Well, in the Ninth Circuit's view, the capacity of an employee at the time of the speech is of some factor. It's a determinative factor. But, in its view, it was a factor that should be weighed against finding no constitutional protection. In its view - -

completeLines.speaker: CONNOR
completeLines.speech: Do you think that the proper application of Pickering would yield a different result in this case?

completeLines.speaker: LEE
completeLines.speech: Our view is that - -

completeLines.speaker: CONNOR
completeLines.speech: Could it?

completeLines.speaker: LEE
completeLines.speech: -- if the application of the Pickering is rearticulated such that when job-required speech is at issue, like in this case, the employer should invariably win or have a -- an easier time of prevailing. But, in this case, the Ninth Circuit didn't see it that way. The Ninth Circuit took the view that the capacity of an employee at the time of the speech is a factor, but it would be difficult for an employer to justify employment decisions made when the employee is speaking as required by the duties of employment.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SOUTER
completeLines.speech: Counsel, you've made the point that if we go the Ninth Circuit way, every time an employee gets in Dutch there's a potential first amendment issue. Why hasn't that been a problem since 1988 in the Ninth Circuit? I think 1988 was the year of the Circuit's Roth decision. So, we haven't seen a deluge, and doesn't that rather discount your argument?

completeLines.speaker: LEE
completeLines.speech: Well, our view is that if we accept the Ninth Circuit's approach, then speech by public employees expressed while carrying out their assigned job duties would virtually -- invariably be - -

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SOUTER
completeLines.speech: No.

completeLines.speaker: LEE
completeLines.speech: -- a matter - -

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SOUTER
completeLines.speech: I realize that, but that -- as I understand it, that has been true since the Ninth Circuit's Roth decision in 1988. And apparently we have not seen a deluge of these claims, or we would have had citations to the cases. So, doesn't that rather discount the concern that you express?

completeLines.speaker: LEE
completeLines.speech: Not necessarily. The Ninth Circuit and the other circuits that have made, primarily, content the determinative factor in finding presumptive first- amendment protection have, in some regards, considered the capacity of an employee as whether or not the speech should be protected under the first amendment, but they've done so in the context of whether or not it is a matter of public concern. So, the Ninth Circuit is alone in having addressed squarely whether or not job-required speech should not be afforded presumptive first-amendment protection. The other - -

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SOUTER
completeLines.speech: But didn't -- maybe I'm wrong on my assumption, but didn't the Ninth Circuit take that position, back in 1988?

completeLines.speaker: LEE
completeLines.speech: That's correct.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SOUTER
completeLines.speech: Okay.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE ROBERTS
completeLines.speech: What do you do with a public university professor, who -- is fired for the content of his lectures? Certainly, in the course of his employment, that's what he's paid to do. That has no first-amendment protection?

completeLines.speaker: LEE
completeLines.speech: Well, it would be our view that if the assigned job duties of that university professor was to speak on a particular topic or content, and they were getting paid for doing that, that that is a job-required speech and that it should not be entitled, presumptively, to first-amendment protection. Now, that is a far cry from - -

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE ROBERTS
completeLines.speech: "Should not be entitled, presumptively, to first-amendment protection," what does that mean? That there might be first amendment protection, in light of the particular context - -

completeLines.speaker: LEE
completeLines.speech: Our - -

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE ROBERTS
completeLines.speech: -- of the speech?

completeLines.speaker: LEE
completeLines.speech: Well, according to the Ninth Circuit's view, anything -- anytime a public employee speaks, and that speech relates to a matter of public concern, that is presumptively entitled to first-amendment protection, such that the burden is on the employer to justify the decisions for the employment actions taken. Our view is that the employer should not have that burden until the first threshold is made, that the speech is expressed as a citizen on a matter of public concern.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SCALIA
completeLines.speech: I suppose that, in the situation the Chief Justice mentioned, the professor would still be able to contend that the university fired him because it disagreed with the political content of his speech or because of the university's politics. He could still make that claim, couldn't he?

completeLines.speaker: LEE
completeLines.speech: Our approach would not prohibit that --

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SCALIA
completeLines.speech: But the - -

completeLines.speaker: LEE
completeLines.speech: -- kind of - -

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SCALIA
completeLines.speech: -- burden would be on him, as it would be in most cases - -

completeLines.speaker: LEE
completeLines.speech: That's correct, Justice Scalia.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SCALIA
completeLines.speech: -- to show that that was true.

completeLines.speaker: LEE
completeLines.speech: That's correct.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SCALIA
completeLines.speech: Whereas, the Ninth Circuit would put it on the -- put the burden on the university to show that it wasn't true.

completeLines.speaker: LEE
completeLines.speech: That's correct. The ninth - -

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE ROBERTS
completeLines.speech: I would have thought you might have argued that it's speech paid for by the Government, that's what they pay him for, it's their speech; and so, there's no first-amendment issue at all.

completeLines.speaker: LEE
completeLines.speech: In essence, the principle of our approach is supported by those Government subsidizer cases, like the Rust v. Sullivan. Our - -

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE GINSBURG
completeLines.speech: But in Rust v. Sullivan, the Government was buying a commodity. It was the Government's program, and it was employing people, funding people to implement that program. Here is a person whose job includes being candid, serving justice, serving truth. If that's part of his job responsibilities, that's quite different from speaking the speech that the Government wants spoken.

completeLines.speaker: LEE
completeLines.speech: Well, in this case, we think that the job duties are aligned with those subsidizer cases. We have a deputy district attorney whose job duty was to assess the merits of the prosecution's case, which he did. That includes assessing the credibility of a witness. Because his conclusions in this case were that the prosecution's witness was not very credible does not make that task extraordinary.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SCALIA
completeLines.speech: I guess if your job is to speak truth, and you speak falsehood, that's a good reason to fire you, which is what happened here.

completeLines.speaker: LEE
completeLines.speech: That could be a - -

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE STEVENS
completeLines.speech: But you don't - -

completeLines.speaker: LEE
completeLines.speech: -- legitimate reason. Or - -

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE STEVENS
completeLines.speech: -- contend that, do you?

completeLines.speaker: LEE
completeLines.speech: -- or the employer doesn't - -

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE STEVENS
completeLines.speech: Do you contend - -

completeLines.speaker: LEE
completeLines.speech: -- necessarily have to - -

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE STEVENS
completeLines.speech: -- that his statement was false? Do you contend the speech was false?

completeLines.speaker: LEE
completeLines.speech: Our position is that the speech was inaccurate and that - -

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SOUTER
completeLines.speech: Well, but how do we know that? We're at summary judgment.

completeLines.speaker: LEE
completeLines.speech: Well, we have the -- the deputy district attorney's disposition memorandum assessed that -- in his view, that the prosecution was going to lose on the pending motion to dismiss, in -- on the grounds of that the search warrant was going to be -- was going to be found invalid. That was the essence of the deputy district attorney's assessment. And in his memorandum, as part of his prosecutorial duties, he evaluated that. He told his supervisor, "Look, you know, I'm looking at the credibility of the officer. I conducted an investigation. I don't think we're going to win on this case." The supervisor initially thought, "Okay, you have a point," but ultimately decided, "You know what? I'm not as sure as you are. We have a motion to traverse on calendar, where we have a judge who's going to be assessing that, so let's see what happens." That judge found that the search warrant was valid. And so, in essence, we have a public employee who is challenging employment decisions made by his supervisors - -

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SOUTER
completeLines.speech: No, I realize that, but where do you -- how do you infer, from that, that the individual, the employee, was not telling the truth?

completeLines.speaker: LEE
completeLines.speech: That - -

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SOUTER
completeLines.speech: If - -

completeLines.speaker: LEE
completeLines.speech: It is not our - -

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SOUTER
completeLines.speech: -- if I - -

completeLines.speaker: LEE
completeLines.speech: -- position - -

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SOUTER
completeLines.speech: -- if my ethical record amounted to a lie every time I made a -- an inaccurate prediction about what a court was going to do when I was a young lawyer, I would have had a very short career.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SOUTER
completeLines.speech: And that seems to me as much as you can infer from what this individual did.

completeLines.speaker: LEE
completeLines.speech: Justice Souter, it is not our position, and we have never taken the stance, that the deputy district attorney in this case was reckless in regards of his speech - -

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SOUTER
completeLines.speech: Oh. Oh. Okay.

completeLines.speaker: LEE
completeLines.speech: -- or his evaluation.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SOUTER
completeLines.speech: So, we don't - -

completeLines.speaker: LEE
completeLines.speech: Our view is that - -

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SOUTER
completeLines.speech: -- we don't know why it didn't pan out the way he said it was going to, and we don't know that he was -- that he was lying.

completeLines.speaker: LEE
completeLines.speech: Correct. What - -

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SOUTER
completeLines.speech: Okay.

completeLines.speaker: LEE
completeLines.speech: -- we do know is that the -- it is our view that the supervisor -- while the supervisor contended that he did not react to this speech adversely, that he could have. We have here speech that was required by the job. The employee here -- if we take the Ninth Circuit's approach, we would be providing public employees a constitutional right to perform their assigned job- required duties in a way that is to the dissatisfaction of the public employer.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SCALIA
completeLines.speech: You don't have to establish that he was lying; just that his prediction -- his job, was to predict, and he made a -- an erroneous -- a false prediction. Don't have to show that he intended to do that.

completeLines.speaker: LEE
completeLines.speech: That's correct, Justice Scalia.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE STEVENS
completeLines.speech: Yes, but the disposition by the -- I mean, his grievance by the hearing examiner was that there was no retaliation. He assumed that the speech was proper and there was no inefficiency or misconduct on the part of the speaker.

completeLines.speaker: LEE
completeLines.speech: Well, the internal grievance procedure resulted in the finding that the supervisors did not retaliate against the deputy district attorney for the -- for his job-required duties.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE STEVENS
completeLines.speech: And, in my understanding, that was the only defense that was made for the charge, that, "We didn't retaliate." There was no claim that the speech was improper in any way. Am I wrong on that?

completeLines.speaker: LEE
completeLines.speech: That's correct - -

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE STEVENS
completeLines.speech: Yes.

completeLines.speaker: LEE
completeLines.speech: -- Justice Stevens.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE STEVENS
completeLines.speech: So, we assume, for purposes of our case, that what he said was totally accurate and did not, itself, provide the basis for saying he was incompetent or something of that -- like that.

completeLines.speaker: LEE
completeLines.speech: Well, we assume, for purposes of the summary judgment motion, that he was within his prosecutorial duties in making those assessments.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE STEVENS
completeLines.speech: Can I ask you one - -

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SCALIA
completeLines.speech: Excuse me, I'm not sure I understood the answer to the first question, John. Was he not fired because he had made an improper assessment?

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE STEVENS
completeLines.speech: No.

completeLines.speaker: LEE
completeLines.speech: No, our position has never been that the supervisors took any retaliatory action as a result of his speech. He was not fired. What the - -

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SCALIA
completeLines.speech: Yes.

completeLines.speaker: LEE
completeLines.speech: -- deputy district attorney - -

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SCALIA
completeLines.speech: Right.

completeLines.speaker: LEE
completeLines.speech: -- challenges here is various employment decisions by his supervisor, claiming that they were in retaliation for him having prepared and communicated a disposition memorandum that was within the course and scope of his employment duties.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SCALIA
completeLines.speech: And your defense is that the - -

completeLines.speaker: LEE
completeLines.speech: Our - -

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SCALIA
completeLines.speech: -- actions were not taken with any reference to this -- to this at all.

completeLines.speaker: LEE
completeLines.speech: -- our position has been that the employer could certainly have reacted, or responded, to the speech or the way he conducted his job, or performed his job, but they didn't, in this case. There were -- there were legitimate business reasons for the employment --

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SCALIA
completeLines.speech: But that's surely a - -

completeLines.speaker: LEE
completeLines.speech: -- decisions made.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SCALIA
completeLines.speech: -- surely a factual inquiry, which will be disputed. If you want to win on summary judgment, it seems to me you have to establish that, assuming he was fired because of this speech, that would be -- or not promoted because of his speech -- that would be perfectly okay.

completeLines.speaker: LEE
completeLines.speech: That's correct - -

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SCALIA
completeLines.speech: That's where - -

completeLines.speaker: LEE
completeLines.speech: -- Justice Scalia.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SCALIA
completeLines.speech: -- we are.

completeLines.speaker: LEE
completeLines.speech: That's - -

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SCALIA
completeLines.speech: We assume - -

completeLines.speaker: LEE
completeLines.speech: -- that's correct.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SCALIA
completeLines.speech: -- that that was the reason for the later actions.

completeLines.speaker: LEE
completeLines.speech: And the problem with the Ninth Circuit's approach is that every time there is job performance at issue that's required by the public employee, it essentially puts the question before a jury or a Federal court to assess the motives - -

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE GINSBURG
completeLines.speech: But what is your position?

completeLines.speaker: LEE
completeLines.speech: -- to assess the reasonableness of the decisions made.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE GINSBURG
completeLines.speech: Ms. Lee, is your position that job-required speech -- an assistant district attorney's obligation is to give his best opinion -- that job-required speech is outside the first-amendment protection? You say the Ninth Circuit went too far, in one way. But are you saying that as long as it's related to his job, it's simply not protected by the first amendment? Is that your position?

completeLines.speaker: LEE
completeLines.speech: Our view is that job-required speech is not of a character for which principles of first amendment should protect. In Pickering, the public school teacher sought to be treated as a member of the general public when he sent his letter to the newspaper criticizing the allocation of financial resources by the school board.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE GINSBURG
completeLines.speech: Yes, I understand - -

completeLines.speaker: LEE
completeLines.speech: Nothing like that arises - -

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE GINSBURG
completeLines.speech: -- I understand that, but I was confused by your answer to Justice O'Connor, because the question was, Would this come out a different way under Pickering? And I take it your answer is, this doesn't come in the door, because he's not speaking as a citizen.

completeLines.speaker: LEE
completeLines.speech: Under the current -- my -- under my current understanding of the Pickering balancing -- which is -- shifts the burden to the employer to justify the employment decisions made -- that we don't -- I don't necessarily believe that the Pickering would clearly weigh in favor of the employer in this case, even though the speech was so connected to the duties of employment - -

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE GINSBURG
completeLines.speech: I'm confused. You think that this -- there was an aspect of it that was citizen speech? Why - -

completeLines.speaker: LEE
completeLines.speech: No.

completeLines.speaker: LEE
completeLines.speech: We contend that it should -- in situations where the speech at issue is job-required, and that employee is getting paid for engaging in that kind of duty, that the balance should weigh in favor of the employer. And I believe the respondent - -

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE GINSBURG
completeLines.speech: Well, what do you mean - -

completeLines.speaker: LEE
completeLines.speech: -- concedes as much.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE GINSBURG
completeLines.speech: -- by "the balance, weigh in favor"? Because, a moment ago, I thought you answered me, "This kind of speech simply is not shielded by the" - -

completeLines.speaker: LEE
completeLines.speech: That's correct.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE GINSBURG
completeLines.speech: -- "first amendment."

completeLines.speaker: LEE
completeLines.speech: Our -- the -- our view is that job- required speech should not be protected under the first amendment, so there is no need to go into the balancing, there is no need to go into the weighing of the interests of the employer versus the interest of the employee. The balancing has been required in the -- in the line of cases that the Court has held -- the language that the Court has used in this first-amendment public-employment context is, when you do the balancing, you weigh the interests of the State, as an employer, versus the interests of the employee, as a citizen, when engaging in this speech. Our view is that the balancing should only be required when the - -

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE STEVENS
completeLines.speech: You would give - -

completeLines.speaker: LEE
completeLines.speech: -- public employee - -

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE STEVENS
completeLines.speech: -- greater protection to a public speech than to a comment from -- on the job from -- to one's superior. Can you give me an example of a statement that would provide -- be entitled to complete first-amendment protection if made in a speech, but could justify a discharge if made face to face with your employer?

completeLines.speaker: LEE
completeLines.speech: I'm sorry, could you repeat that?

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE STEVENS
completeLines.speech: Could you give me an example of a statement that would be protected in a public speech, but, if made privately to your superior, could provide the basis for a discharge?

completeLines.speaker: LEE
completeLines.speech: I believe the Court's referring to facts similar to Givhan, where there you had speech made privately to a supervisor, and - -

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE STEVENS
completeLines.speech: Which was - -

completeLines.speaker: LEE
completeLines.speech: -- this Court - -

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE STEVENS
completeLines.speech: -- protected.

completeLines.speaker: LEE
completeLines.speech: -- this Court has found that it was protected under the first amendment.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE STEVENS
completeLines.speech: Yes.

completeLines.speaker: LEE
completeLines.speech: However, the Court did not need to address the role of the speaker in that case, because there you had an English teacher who was criticizing the racial - -

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE STEVENS
completeLines.speech: You're not - -

completeLines.speaker: LEE
completeLines.speech: -- policies - -

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE STEVENS
completeLines.speech: -- responding to my question. My question is, Can you give me an example of a statement that would be entitled to protection if made in a public speech, but could be a basis for discharge if made face to face?

completeLines.speaker: LEE
completeLines.speech: It could be in this case, where the prosecutor, who is assigned, or authorized, to speak on behalf of the DA's office in a pending criminal action, made comments to the press about the nature of the case, but, rather -- and, in this particular scenario, goes too far, goes beyond what the DA's office allowed him to speak on.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE STEVENS
completeLines.speech: No, I'm - -

completeLines.speaker: LEE
completeLines.speech: He could - -

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE STEVENS
completeLines.speech: -- asking you if - -

completeLines.speaker: LEE
completeLines.speech: -- certainly be discharged for that.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE STEVENS
completeLines.speech: -- what he says privately could the basis for a discharge. Surely, he couldn't be discharged for what you just described.

completeLines.speaker: LEE
completeLines.speech: The -- under our approach, the issue is not whether it's privately or publicly. If the job requires him to speak in a -- within the internal channels, then that speech -- he's doing his job, he's getting paid for it, and he should not be entitled to first-amendment protection. Unless there are any other questions - -

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SOUTER
completeLines.speech: Is that - -

completeLines.speaker: LEE
completeLines.speech: -- I'd like to - -

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SOUTER
completeLines.speech: -- is that true in this case? I realize they didn't get to it on summary judgment, but is that true in this case with respect to a Brady disclosure?

completeLines.speaker: LEE
completeLines.speech: Brady disclosures are the obligations of the district attorney's office. So, in this case, when the deputy district attorney believed that it should be disclosed, his supervisor had an absolute right to, say, on behalf of the DA's office, challenge that decision to disclose.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SOUTER
completeLines.speech: What if -- what if the lawyer simply believes that he has an ethical obligation to make the disclosure, and he makes it, and he is then subject to retaliation? No first amendment claim on his part?

completeLines.speaker: LEE
completeLines.speech: Those ethical obligations would build -- would arise from his capacity as a prosecutor. Prosecutors are employees. Governmental employees have a general standard of ethical conduct. That doesn't mean that they are getting paid for the same assigned job duties.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SOUTER
completeLines.speech: Well, does that mean -- what's your answer to my question? If he makes the Brady disclosure because he believes that is an ethical obligation, and he is then subject to retaliation, does he have a first amendment claim, or not?

completeLines.speaker: LEE
completeLines.speech: It's our view that he does not. I'd like to reserve the remainder of - -

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE ROBERTS
completeLines.speech: Thank you - -

completeLines.speaker: LEE
completeLines.speech: -- my time for rebuttal.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE ROBERTS
completeLines.speech: -- Ms. Lee. Mr. Himmelfarb.

completeLines.speaker: CONNOR
completeLines.speech: What's your answer to that last question, Mr. Himmelfarb?

completeLines.speaker: HIMMELFARB
completeLines.speech: A Brady obligation is an obligation of a prosecutor in his capacity as a prosecutor; and a Brady disclosure, like a recommendation to a superior that there should be a Brady disclosure, constitutes the exercise of the prosecutorial function by a prosecutor. It is employee speech, and that speech, if it engenders an employment action, should not be sufficient for the employee to get past the first step of the Pickering balancing. If there is - -

completeLines.speaker: CONNOR
completeLines.speech: So, no free-speech protection under Pickering.

completeLines.speaker: HIMMELFARB
completeLines.speech: That's exactly right, Justice O'Connor.

completeLines.speaker: CONNOR
completeLines.speech: And how about this case? Could it not be resolved under a proper handling of Pickering?

completeLines.speaker: HIMMELFARB
completeLines.speech: Well, we think a proper handling of Pickering is that respondents should not get past step one of the balancing, because the speech is expressed in his capacity as an employee.

completeLines.speaker: CONNOR
completeLines.speech: Now, what about retaliation claims that the employee may have? What about whistleblower-type claims by an employer? Are they -- are they separate from the first-amendment concerns?

completeLines.speaker: HIMMELFARB
completeLines.speech: We don't think they are, Justice O'Connor, if the whistle-blowing is required by the employee's speech. If an investigator in an inspector general's office, whose job it is to investigate and report government misconduct, reports misconduct, and an action is taken as a result -- an employment action is taken against them as a result -- he is demoted or transferred, because it's the view of his superior that he didn't perform his job properly in speaking on that issue -- that should not enable the investigator to get past the first step.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SCALIA
completeLines.speech: What if the reason -- what if the reason for the -- for firing him is that he's a Democrat and it's a Republican Administration, and the speech is used as the pretext?

completeLines.speaker: HIMMELFARB
completeLines.speech: Justice Scalia, I think that case would be covered by this Court's patronage cases, which would absolutely prohibit that sort of employment action. But in a case where it's not party affiliation that motivates the employment action, if the speech is expressed in carrying out the employee's duties, he may have a civil-service remedy -- indeed, that's precisely what the civil-service laws were designed to deal with, a situation where the employee is just doing his job, an action is taken again him, and there's a dispute as to whether he was doing his job properly, about whether he was insubordinate, or simply about whether he was - -

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: Suppose that we have an instance where it is job related. He is not speaking as a private citizen, and it's also a public concern. Now, in such an instance, could we say that, at least if the matter of public concern rise to the level where it's related to an independent constitutional protection -- say, founded in the due-process clause -- under those circumstances, the employer cannot unreasonably -- though we give him an area of discretion, he cannot unreasonably retaliate.

completeLines.speaker: HIMMELFARB
completeLines.speech: I don't think so, Justice - -

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: Why not?

completeLines.speaker: HIMMELFARB
completeLines.speech: -- Breyer.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: Why not? And here is an independent obligation.

completeLines.speaker: HIMMELFARB
completeLines.speech: To - -

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: It's very unusual - -

completeLines.speaker: HIMMELFARB
completeLines.speech: To - -

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: -- but it's there.

completeLines.speaker: HIMMELFARB
completeLines.speech: To use the example of this case, if respondent advised his supervisor that, in his professional judgment, a Brady disclosure should be made, and if the supervisor disagreed with him, and if reasonable minds could differ as to whether the disclosure should be made, and he made it, nonetheless, he would be insubordinate. And we don't think that that is the - -

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: You'd only lose -- the Government would lose, only where you can conclude that they could -- "they," the Government -- could not -- could not reasonably conclude that he'd been insubordinate.

completeLines.speaker: HIMMELFARB
completeLines.speech: Justice Breyer - -

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: So, we covered the case of the Democrat, Republican, et cetera. In other words, we'd give him -- should we give him total discretion? Can't we limit that discretion of the supervisor?

completeLines.speaker: HIMMELFARB
completeLines.speech: If it's -- if it's a situation where reasonable minds cannot differ, and the superior directs him not to make the disclosure, in clear contravention of the due-process clause as interpreted in Brady, that is a situation - -

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE STEVENS
completeLines.speech: But, Mr. Himmelfarb, in that case he could also be fired if he made the statement in a speech, could he not?

completeLines.speaker: HIMMELFARB
completeLines.speech: If he made the statement in a public speech - -

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE STEVENS
completeLines.speech: Right.

completeLines.speaker: HIMMELFARB
completeLines.speech: -- or in a letter to the editor of a newspaper, we think that speech would be presumptively protected by the first amendment.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE STEVENS
completeLines.speech: But could he not be fired if the scenario you just described as - -

completeLines.speaker: HIMMELFARB
completeLines.speech: Maybe he could, Justice Stevens, but that would be subject to balancing, and it would be the employer's duty to justify the firing, based on workplace disruption.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE STEVENS
completeLines.speech: It seems to me odd that the employee has greater protection if he goes outside the regular channels and makes a speech than if he does -- he goes right to his superior and says, "I think this is what's wrong and should be remedied."

completeLines.speaker: HIMMELFARB
completeLines.speech: Well, it's not that odd, Justice Stevens, because if you have an obligation to report misconduct -- take, again, the example of the investigator in the inspector general's office -- you will ordinarily be better off by reporting it through the ordinary channels.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE STEVENS
completeLines.speech: Right.

completeLines.speaker: HIMMELFARB
completeLines.speech: Because, ordinarily, you have --

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE STEVENS
completeLines.speech: You may have no constitutional protection. But if you go ahead and make a speech, you do.

completeLines.speaker: HIMMELFARB
completeLines.speech: Well, you have presumptive first-amendment protection. If you work in the inspector general's office, and there is a prohibition on disclosing pending investigations, and you hold a press conference, there is a very good chance you're going to lose at step two of Pickering, which is why it's in your interest to disclose it through appropriate channels, because - -

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE ROBERTS
completeLines.speech: And it's going to be clear that that's violating your job, and it has an adverse impact on your job-related duties, because you're going public, instead of going through the channels.

completeLines.speaker: HIMMELFARB
completeLines.speech: Well, that's right. If you have an -- if it's a part of your job, you have an incentive to do it, just like any other job requirement. And it's ordinarily not the case that public employees are punished for doing their jobs. They're more often punished for not doing their jobs. So, in that situation, the employee is going to likely be better off by making the disclosure through appropriate channels.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE STEVENS
completeLines.speech: But he has less constitutional protection.

completeLines.speaker: HIMMELFARB
completeLines.speech: That's true, Justice Stevens, but civil -- it's our view that civil service laws are the mechanism for dealing with a situation where you're doing your job and there's a dispute as to whether you're doing it properly or not.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE ROBERTS
completeLines.speech: How comfortable are you that this line you're trying to draw is one that's going to be workable in practice? I mean, suppose the employee writes a memo, and the boss comes and says, "If you don't promise me you're not going to talk about this publicly, you're fired." And he says, "Well, I'm not going to promise that." And so, he's fired. Now, is that internal, or is that external?

completeLines.speaker: HIMMELFARB
completeLines.speech: If the -- if the memo is required by his job, it's - -

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE ROBERTS
completeLines.speech: Right.

completeLines.speaker: HIMMELFARB
completeLines.speech: -- a recommendation about what policy the agency - -

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE ROBERTS
completeLines.speech: That's - -

completeLines.speaker: HIMMELFARB
completeLines.speech: -- should take - -

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE ROBERTS
completeLines.speech: -- required by his job. But "promise that he's not going to talk about it" is not required by his job. And this case, kind of, raises the question, because the only reason it's squarely presented on the memo is because the Court didn't reach the Brady disclosure or the talk to the bar association that were related to the memo.

completeLines.speaker: HIMMELFARB
completeLines.speech: That's right. In answer to your question of how difficult it's going to be to draw the line, I think in most cases it won't be difficult to draw the line. I don't think it was difficult in this case. I'm not aware of any cases that applied principle we advocate where it has been. There may be some cases where it will be difficult to draw the line, but - -

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE KENNEDY
completeLines.speech: I suppose you have the rule which distinguishes between employment-related and outside speech, under the hypothetical -- difficult hypothetical posed by the Chief Justice, it would be an -- the promise would be an unconstitutional condition, or something like that.

completeLines.speaker: HIMMELFARB
completeLines.speech: That may --

completeLines.speaker: HIMMELFARB
completeLines.speech: -- that may -- that may be, Justice Kennedy.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE KENNEDY
completeLines.speech: I suppose it's a hard case - -

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SCALIA
completeLines.speech: And I suppose that what constitutes a matter of public interest is not the clearest line in the world either, is it?

completeLines.speaker: HIMMELFARB
completeLines.speech: That's absolutely right, Justice Scalia. This Court has already decided that it's important to draw a line at step one in distinguishing between speech on a matter of public concern and speech on a matter of private concern, even though it will often be hard to draw that line. And the reason that line has to be drawn is that the alternative is, in effect, to constitutionalize the law of public employment.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SOUTER
completeLines.speech: Do you -- let me ask you this -- do you propose drawing the line -- or at least drawing a line in some circumstances this way: That, at step one, if it can be concluded that a private communication between the employer and the employee would have constituted the discharge of the employee's assigned work -- so that it would have been within the scope of his employment, and, therefore, not subject to Pickering balancing, if he had made the statement to the employer -- that, therefore, the statement cannot be regarded as a statement of public interest, even if he had disclosed it publicly, or if he took a further step and went to the bar association and whatnot?

completeLines.speaker: HIMMELFARB
completeLines.speech: Justice Souter, we see these as two separate requirements to get past step one. The speech has to be on a matter of public concern, but it also has to be speech in the speaker's capacity as a citizen.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SOUTER
completeLines.speech: But if it is within -- I'm sorry, but if it -- if it is within the speaker's assigned duties as an employee, does that preclude a conclusion, later on, that he was speaking as a citizen, even if he goes public with it?

completeLines.speaker: HIMMELFARB
completeLines.speech: I don't think it does, Justice Souter. If - -

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SOUTER
completeLines.speech: So, we do have, then, the problem that Justice Stevens has raised.

completeLines.speaker: HIMMELFARB
completeLines.speech: That's right. I don't -- I don't see it as much of a problem, for the reasons I tried to give in responding to Justice Stevens.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE GINSBURG
completeLines.speech: What about the hearing at which this office had testified? I thought that part of the complaint was, "When I spoke at the hearing, I was speaking in a public forum, and they fired me for it."

completeLines.speaker: HIMMELFARB
completeLines.speech: May I answer the question?

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE ROBERTS
completeLines.speech: Yes.

completeLines.speaker: HIMMELFARB
completeLines.speech: My understanding is that that's not part of the complaint, Justice Ginsburg. And my understanding also is that, in the district court, respondent took the position that his testimony at the hearing was in his capacity as an employee.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE ROBERTS
completeLines.speech: Thank you, Mr. Himmelfarb. Ms. Robin-Vergeer.

completeLines.speaker: VERGEER
completeLines.speech: Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court: Ever since Pickering, it has been the law that the first amendment protects public employees from being fired or punished for expressing views on matters of public importance where, as here, there is no harm or disruption to their employers. Petitioners in -- the United States asked this Court to scrap that. It is not just the Ninth Circuit.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SCALIA
completeLines.speech: Well, it - -

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE KENNEDY
completeLines.speech: Well, I'm not sure that that was clear from the decisions of this Court. Certainly, that wasn't what was involved in Pickering. That was outside speech.

completeLines.speaker: VERGEER
completeLines.speech: That's correct. But it's been the - -

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE KENNEDY
completeLines.speech: And the same -- and the same with Connick. So, I'm -- if you're saying that this is what the circuits have understood, fine, but that's not this -- that's why we took this case.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SCALIA
completeLines.speech: And I think all the cases did say "expressing views as a citizen on a matter of public concern." Wasn't that qualifier always used?

completeLines.speaker: VERGEER
completeLines.speech: The qualifier has always been used in conjunction with the phase "on matters of public concern."

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SCALIA
completeLines.speech: So, what does it mean? What is -- what is your explanation for that qualifier, "expressing views as a citizen"? Why do we - -

completeLines.speaker: VERGEER
completeLines.speech: It - -

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SCALIA
completeLines.speech: -- continually say that?

completeLines.speaker: VERGEER
completeLines.speech: -- it was used descriptively to explain, and especially to look at the context in which the phrase first appears, in Pickering, that public employees, like all citizens, have an interest - -

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE KENNEDY
completeLines.speech: Well, let's assume that - -

completeLines.speaker: VERGEER
completeLines.speech: -- on matters - -

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE KENNEDY
completeLines.speech: -- I think that that's an open question under Pickering, and that this case presents it. Do you -- do you concede -- and maybe you don't -- that there is any category of first amendment speech, as a matter of public concern, which an employee cannot direct to the employer? Are there -- are there some matters as to which the employer can protect its own interests and stifle the employee's speech?

completeLines.speaker: VERGEER
completeLines.speech: Speaking on a matter of public concern only gets the employee presumptive first- amendment protection.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE KENNEDY
completeLines.speech: So, there's always Pickering balance.

completeLines.speaker: VERGEER
completeLines.speech: There would be a Pickering balance, yes. And the Pickering balancing test is quite deferential to the employer. The Court observed, in the Pickering case, that it's proper to look -- that a court should look at the proper performance of the employee's daily duties. In Rankin, the Court talked about the questions whether the speech interferes with work, personnel relationships, or the speaker's job performance. The bar is already quite high for the employee, coupled with causation burdens, qualified immunity, and so on. And so, it is not the case that just because a -- an employee speaks on a matter of public concern, that that employee is necessarily going to win a first-amendment case. Also - -

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE GINSBURG
completeLines.speech: Ms. Lee -- Ms. Lee told us that the Ninth Circuit weighed the capacity of the plaintiff as an employee, rather than a member of the public, in favor of the employee and against the employer. Is that how you read the Ninth Circuit's decision?

completeLines.speaker: VERGEER
completeLines.speech: No, I think -- it's not quite right. I think the Ninth Circuit just looked at whether his speech which was reporting Government misconduct, a type of speech that the circuit said uniformly recognized was of paramount public importance.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE KENNEDY
completeLines.speech: But - -

completeLines.speaker: VERGEER
completeLines.speech: And - -

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE KENNEDY
completeLines.speech: -- any comment that an employee makes regarding how the office is working is a matter of public concern. I would concede that. I mean --

completeLines.speaker: VERGEER
completeLines.speech: With - -

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE KENNEDY
completeLines.speech: -- that has to be.

completeLines.speaker: VERGEER
completeLines.speech: -- with respect, I don't - -

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE KENNEDY
completeLines.speech: And the consequence of your view is to have the first amendment being used for courts to monitor the discussions that take place in every public agency -- local, State, and Federal -- in the United States. It's -- you are advocating a sweeping rule. Now, you'll say, "Oh, well, Pickering balance will protect it."

completeLines.speaker: VERGEER
completeLines.speech: With - -

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE KENNEDY
completeLines.speech: But I still think the intrusive consequences of your -- of your rule are sweeping.

completeLines.speaker: VERGEER
completeLines.speech: With respect, the public- concern threshold is not so easily met. the Court has said - -

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: I guess our law clerks would meet it every day.

completeLines.speaker: VERGEER
completeLines.speech: Maybe. Maybe not.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: Yeah, maybe, maybe not. I don't - -

completeLines.speaker: VERGEER
completeLines.speech: But the Court has - -

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: -- anything that goes on in my chamber that isn't a matter of public concern, and I would think everything at OSHA and everything at -- look, I'll -- let me put my question to you, because you're going to make an argument that I don't think is too widely shared; namely, that Pickering decides this case. If that's your argument, I'd like to ask you a question based on the assumption Pickering does not decide this case. And it seems to me that Pickering involves a case in which it's both a matter of public concern and outside the scope of employment.

completeLines.speaker: VERGEER
completeLines.speech: Right.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: And here we have a case that is a matter of public concern, but inside.

completeLines.speaker: VERGEER
completeLines.speech: Right. I - -

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: So, in those circumstances, I want to know how you believe the first amendment requires us to decide this case. And as I read this case, in the record, we have one individual, your client, who looked at an affidavit. The affidavit said that the deputy sheriffs were trying to locate where a vehicle that was chocked up came from. They saw tire tracks. The tire tracks went back to a fence at the end of a long driveway. So, I looked in the record. I couldn't find the affidavit. So, I assume that's what it says. And I wanted to know what the deputy sheriff said. What they said is that your client agreed that there were tire tracks. There were tire tracks that did not go the whole length of the driveway, but, rather, tire tracks near the house, where they got the search warrant for. And, they added, that -- the deputies -- that there was rocks broken up. All right. So, we have two sides to this argument: the deputies, who might reasonably contend that they did nothing wrong; your client, who thinks they were lying. And we also have a letter that your client wrote, where he said that these deputies are grossly inaccurate and clearly misleading. Suppose his supervisor goes to him and says, "I think that that letter is not the right tone. Maybe you're right, maybe you're wrong; maybe they're in good faith, maybe they're not. And so, if you don't change that tone, I'm going to discipline you." All right? Now, that's my hypothetical, which seemed to me, perhaps, very much like this case. How, in your opinion, does the first amendment handle such a matter?

completeLines.speaker: VERGEER
completeLines.speech: If the supervisor told Mr. Ceballos that there was something wrong in the manner in which he conveyed his speech, and told him to revise the memo, that would have been -- he would have been well within his rights to do so. Bear in mind that there's never been an argument here that there was anything inappropriate about Mr. Ceballos's speech, that he exercised poor judgment, that there was anything disruptive about the manner in which he communicated. The head of the office - -

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE KENNEDY
completeLines.speech: But I don't under- --

completeLines.speaker: VERGEER
completeLines.speech: -- actually said - -

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE KENNEDY
completeLines.speech: -- I understand the ultimate answer you gave the hypothetical. I don't understand the principle you're following. I mean, it's a matter of --

completeLines.speaker: VERGEER
completeLines.speech: It's - -

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE KENNEDY
completeLines.speech: -- you would agree this is a matter of public concern.

completeLines.speaker: VERGEER
completeLines.speech: Yes.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: Which is what I'm looking - -

completeLines.speaker: VERGEER
completeLines.speech: Yes.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: -- for. I'm looking for - -

completeLines.speaker: VERGEER
completeLines.speech: It is - -

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: -- a standard.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE KENNEDY
completeLines.speech: But we don't have a standard.

completeLines.speaker: VERGEER
completeLines.speech: The principle is that an employer -- we agree with the position of the United States, that the employer has the ability to dictate how an employee carries out his duties. In a case where the employee - -

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE ROBERTS
completeLines.speech: But in Justice - -

completeLines.speaker: VERGEER
completeLines.speech: -- is insubordinate - -

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE ROBERTS
completeLines.speech: -- in Justice Breyer's hypothetical, if the employee filed a lawsuit claiming a violation of his first-amendment rights, you would say that could not be thrown out, on summary judgment, on the ground that the speech was within the scope of his employment.

completeLines.speaker: VERGEER
completeLines.speech: It would be not on that ground.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE ROBERTS
completeLines.speech: No.

completeLines.speaker: VERGEER
completeLines.speech: The reason it would be thrown out in summary judgment would be because the employer had a different reason for taking retaliatory action - -

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: No, no there is --

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE ROBERTS
completeLines.speech: Well, that would - -

completeLines.speaker: VERGEER
completeLines.speech: -- against the employee.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE ROBERTS
completeLines.speech: -- be a dispute of fact, so it probably wouldn't -- so it wouldn't be thrown at summary judgment at all.

completeLines.speaker: VERGEER
completeLines.speech: Virtually all of these cases are able to be disposed of at summary judgment. And you have, basically, 20 years of litigation in the circuit courts to look at where - -

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: Look --

completeLines.speaker: VERGEER
completeLines.speech: -- the problems that are being posited haven't materialized.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: I'm not making my question too clear. I imagine the district judge. I get just the facts I described to you. Your client, who's very upset, says, "This is the most unreasonable thing that ever happened. They were trying to prevent me from communicating with the judge. I'm the one who saw the sheriffs. They didn't." The other side says, "We think it's reasonable what we did." My question to you is, What standard does that judge apply under the first amendment? What does he do?

completeLines.speaker: VERGEER
completeLines.speech: The judge looks first at whether the speech is on a matter of public concern. And if it's a dispute over Government misconduct, it would meet that threshold. Second, the Court would proceed to a Pickering balance and would say the employer's actual reason for retaliating or taking action would be because of the -- you know, the tone or the message or because it was a disagreement, and the supervisor's views ultimately prevail. And so, that's how it would be - -

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE KENNEDY
completeLines.speech: So, the Federal - -

completeLines.speaker: VERGEER
completeLines.speech: -- analyzed.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE KENNEDY
completeLines.speech: -- Federal courts supervise the constant dialogue that is the everyday routine practice in every governmental agency, local and Federal, in the United States.

completeLines.speaker: VERGEER
completeLines.speech: With respect, no. These cases are not that hard to dispose of at summary judgment. Most actions that employers take against the employees are not because of the employees' speech anyway, it's because of how they carry out their job functions.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE GINSBURG
completeLines.speech: But that would be something that would have to go to trial, to prove that the -- that the employee was incompetent.

completeLines.speaker: VERGEER
completeLines.speech: Respectfully, I don't -- I don't think that most of these cases -- they don't go to trial, most of them. They're -- of course, there are some trials, but that is not the way most of these cases are handled. And, besides that, adding an extra test, another preliminary hurdle, wouldn't change the litigation burden. Instead of it being the Connick-Pickering test, it would be Connick-Pickering-Ceballos test. And then the question would be, Was the person doing their job? How do you decide that? Is it in his job description? Is it a matter of custom and practice? What if he's doing extra- credit work to build up goodwill with his employer, but it's something that's not - -

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE KENNEDY
completeLines.speech: Well, in - -

completeLines.speaker: VERGEER
completeLines.speech: -- ordinarily required?

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE KENNEDY
completeLines.speech: -- in this case, the supervisor said, "There can't be -- can't be tracks on asphalt, so you're probably right." Then he finds out that it's a tire rim, and of course the rim makes a -- so we have to find out this at discovery -- at the discovery stage of a lawsuit?

completeLines.speaker: VERGEER
completeLines.speech: As long as he's made an -- as long as he's made allegations or spoken in good faith in their -- and it isn't demonstrably false, then he would clear that initial hurdle. And there certainly was nothing suggesting that he spoke in bad faith or was obviously false, whether or not he was correct in his assessment. And it wasn't just an argument over a tire rim. He accused these -- the deputy sheriff here of perjury. It was a quite serious allegation of Government misconduct that was made here, and not, sort of, a mundane dispute over - -

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE ROBERTS
completeLines.speech: Why doesn't - -

completeLines.speaker: VERGEER
completeLines.speech: -- whether or not - -

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE ROBERTS
completeLines.speech: -- why doesn't Rust answer this question? I mean, there, it was really -- this issue was just outsourced by the Government. They paid for the speech there, and we said that if you pay the piper, you get to call the tune. And this is just an insourced -- the same question.

completeLines.speaker: VERGEER
completeLines.speech: Ceballos was not speaking on behalf of the Government when he went to his supervisor. That was an internal communication to his supervisor reporting - -

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE ROBERTS
completeLines.speech: He was writing a memo about why the case should be dismissed. Wasn't - -

completeLines.speaker: VERGEER
completeLines.speech: Right.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE ROBERTS
completeLines.speech: -- that part of his job?

completeLines.speaker: VERGEER
completeLines.speech: It was part of his job, although I -- I'd quibble with the idea that it was required by his job. But it was part of his job. And, in doing so, he spoke to the Government, not as the Government. A better analogy with respect to Rust would be if the doctor in Rust -- let's say it's a doctor at a public university hospital, and the doctor was told that the policy is not to engage in abortion counseling. And he wrote a memo to the supervisor saying, "This is a terribly policy. This is inhibiting our ability to counsel my patients and for me to do my job correctly." That memo would not be the Government's message. And Ceballos's memo here to his supervisor was also not the Government's message. But I want to -- I want to get - -

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE ROBERTS
completeLines.speech: Well, why is that? In the -- in your hypothetical, the doctor is -- it's not his job to challenge the restriction on the Government grant, but that's what he's doing, so that's not part of his job. Here, it's part of Ceballos's job to explain why the case should be dismissed, and that's what he wrote in his memo.

completeLines.speaker: VERGEER
completeLines.speech: But this is a very malleable and manipulable concept, what's part of a job. I mean, for a doctor to talk to his supervisor about a restriction that he feels is inhibiting his ability to counsel his patients is as much part of his job as a prosecutor going to his supervisor and saying, "There's government misconduct in this case, and we need to do something about it." Just like a teacher in the Givhan case, going to her principal, a conference between a teacher and her principal about whether there's racial -- racially discriminatory practices in the school would be part of a teacher's job, complaining about something that affects her students.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE ROBERTS
completeLines.speech: What do you do with your friend's response to that, that in Connick the Court characterized Givhan as involving a case of a citizen complaining about a particular practice?

completeLines.speaker: VERGEER
completeLines.speech: Well, I think that underscores the point, that the employee in Givhan was speaking both as an employee and as a citizen, and these roles are not mutually exclusive. You can be both. There's no artificial distinction that the Court has drawn here. And where a Government employee comes forward and reports misconduct and puts himself at risk, he is doing just that, speaking in both capacities. And - -

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SCALIA
completeLines.speech: We just shouldn't have said "as a citizen" in all of these cases. We were just padding our opinion with unnecessary words.

completeLines.speaker: VERGEER
completeLines.speech: the Court -- the Court always views the "as a citizen" language in conjunction with the -- speaking on a matter of public concern. And it seems to me that the Court equated the two concepts. But I want to get to why it is unwise and unjustified to draw the per se rule that petitioners are urging here. For one, it essentially means that a public employee such as Ceballos has to go public in order to have presumptive first-amendment protection.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE GINSBURG
completeLines.speech: But then he would be violating the internal rules of the workplace.

completeLines.speaker: VERGEER
completeLines.speech: Correct.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE GINSBURG
completeLines.speech: Where as giving his candid views -- the search warrant -- he's giving his own opinion. But if he goes outside, he is violating a rule of the workplace. And it would seem to me that there are certainly measures could be taken against him for that.

completeLines.speaker: VERGEER
completeLines.speech: Correct. It's a trap. They don't tell you about what happened in the second case. If Ceballos had taken suspicions of police misconduct and gone to the Los Angeles Times, they would have fired him. And had he brought a case challenging that termination under the first amendment, he would have lost on under the Pickering balance. The circuit - -

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE ROBERTS
completeLines.speech: Do you think he should have lost under the Pickering balance, in that case, if he went public right away?

completeLines.speaker: VERGEER
completeLines.speech: Yes. If he had evaded proper internal channels of communication, then the employer would be well within his rights to fire him for taking an action that's so disruptive in bringing -- discrediting the office without even letting his own employer try to address the situation internally first.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SOUTER
completeLines.speech: What if he does let the employer try first, and the employer does nothing, then he goes public? Where does the Pickering balance come out then?

completeLines.speaker: VERGEER
completeLines.speech: Closer question. I think he probably still loses, but it's a closer question. I think, at some point, if the magnitude of this -- of the problem is so large -- I mean, imagine in the Ramparts scandal situation if -- which has been discussed in the briefs -- if a prosecutor tried to deal with that within the DA's office, and failed to get any response, and then went public with the Ramparts scandal, something of such magnitude, a court perhaps would find their way. But in the - -

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE KENNEDY
completeLines.speech: What - -

completeLines.speaker: VERGEER
completeLines.speech: -- individual - -

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE KENNEDY
completeLines.speech: -- what you're saying is, is that the first amendment has an office and a function within the confines of a Government agency that it doesn't have outside. That's a curious calculus. It seems to me that the first amendment has its most application when you talk to newspapers, when you talk outside. That's what the first amendment's about. The first amendment isn't about policing the workplace.

completeLines.speaker: VERGEER
completeLines.speech: the Court held, in both Givhan and Rankin, that private communications on matters of public concern are still protected. completeLines.speaker: LEE
completeLines.speech: Under our approach, we believe that many cases won't even be filed, because they won't be able to make a colorable claim that it is citizen speech. This case, in its essence, is about whether a public employee has a constitutional right to perform his assigned job duties in such a way that is to the dissatisfaction of the employer. In Pickering and in Connick, this Court contemplated first-amendment litigation in a public- employment context in the relatively rare circumstances in which adverse employment action was taken as a result of an employee's extracurricular activities. Under the Ninth Circuit and the respondent's approach, the exception would become the rule.
